hero.title: Driver Trainer Simulator
hero.description: Practice mecanum control and checkpoint runs with a connected gamepad. Swap between robot-centric and field-centric driving and generate randomized training paths on the fly.

sim.title: Mecanum Trainer
sim.description: Use a PS/Xbox controller: Left stick = move, Right stick X = turn.

noController.title: No controller detected.
noController.description: Connect a gamepad and press any button to begin.

status.title: Trainer Status
status.active: Active — follow the glowing checkpoint rings.
status.idle: Idle — start a new run to begin.

tips.title: Tips
items: Keep motion smooth to avoid overshooting checkpoints.
Field-centric mode aligns movement to the field instead of robot heading.
Use New Path to practice different trajectories quickly.
Reset Robot if you drift too far off-center.

aim.title: Joystick OSU-style Trainer
aim.description: Use left/right sticks to hit shrinking circles. Practice timing, accuracy, and stick coordination.
aim.note: Left stick = aim (left field), Right stick = aim (right field). Press Start to begin, Pause/Resume as needed. Change difficulty to adjust spawn speed and timing windows.

posts.title: A Fisherman's Guide to Fusion 360
posts.author: Zhanibek - CAD Engineer
posts.summary: Zhanibek shares the Fusion 360 habits that let us design lighter custom FTC parts even when kit inventories run thin.

fusion-360.title: A Fisherman's Guide to Fusion 360
fusion-360.author: Zhanibek - CAD Engineer
fusion-360.heroAlt: Zhanibek walking through Fusion 360 workflows with the CAD team
fusion-360.intro: Fusion 360 is the quiet superstar of our workshop. In this fisherman-style guide, Zhanibek explains how we lean on Autodesk’s toolkit to model custom FIRST Tech Challenge parts even when off-the-shelf components fall short.

sections.title: What's Fusion 360?
paragraphs: Fusion 360 is the all-in-one environment we trust for robotics: CAD, CAM, rendering, assemblies, and exports in a single window so we never break focus mid-build.

While you can assemble a functioning FTC robot from kit parts alone, modeling and printing your own improves efficiency, trims weight, and offsets the limited supply of REV or goBilda stock in local shops.

sections.title: Part 2. Drivetrain & Color track system
paragraphs: The drivetrain is one of the most important parts of a robot. There are many variations, and the choice doesn’t have to be rigid — you build around mechanisms. There are no strict rules in design, but we will cover popular choices and our solutions.
Wheels
The wheels drive the robot’s motion. Their diameter and motor type also affect programming. We recommend mid motors for the drivetrain (we have a guide for mid motor motion).
Fig 2.1 Wheel 61.6mm D. x 13.6mm
Our 2025 robot used these wheels in combination.

images.alt: Fig 2.1 Wheel 61.6mm D. x 13.6mm
images.caption: Fig. 2.1 — Wheel 61.6mm D. x 13.6mm

sections.title: What do we use it for?
paragraphs: Inside our INTO THE DEEP CAD, every colored component highlights a custom-printed part, and it's nearly every mechanism that manipulates game elements.
The arm, claw, extension, and lift were all tuned digitally before touching printers, which saved plastic, sped up iteration, and let strategy drive geometry.

sections.title: Method 1: "TENET" and the Parametric Timeline
paragraphs: The parametric timeline logs every feature you create, and Fusion 360 lets you edit that ledger—almost like rewinding time TENET-style.
Adjust a dimension, replay the timeline, and the downstream features rebuild automatically. It is how we keep experimentation safe instead of brittle.
bullets: Correct the size of a part when measurements were off.
Fix misaligned joints or constraints without redrawing.
Move sketches that started on the wrong plane.
Extend or shorten extrusions after testing feedback.

sections.title: Method 2: Sketch Me Like One of Your French Girls
paragraphs: Everything begins with sketches raised from the base plane, so rookies master lines, arcs, and circles before they ever extrude.
Constraints are the unsung heroes: Equal keeps lines matched, Coincident locks points together, and fully constrained sketches prevent messy geometry when dimensions change.
bullets: Equal: tie two segments together so scaling one scales the other.
Coincident: snap points (and everything attached) into alignment.
Constraint discipline keeps edits from warping the rest of the sketch.

sections.title: Method 3: Astral Projection with Project & Intersect
paragraphs: Project and Intersect duplicate geometry from other sketches or bodies so you can reference it on a new plane—almost like astral projecting shapes into place.
Those projections stay linked to the original, which means timeline edits ripple through every dependent feature and make late-stage tweaks far less painful.

sections.title: Fusion 360 Build Gallery
paragraphs: Snapshots from the fisherman guide: sketches, constraints, joints, renders, and assembly checks that keep our FTC parts consistent and lightweight.

images.alt: Fusion 360 sketch with constraints applied
Parametric timeline showing editable features
Extrusion and fillet pass on a drivetrain plate
Joint preview verifying rotational clearance
Component breakdown for assembly reuse
Rendered view of the subsystem housing
Exploded view highlighting printed parts

fusion-360.closing: Zhanibek’s fisherman guide boils down to habits: learn the tools, constrain the sketches, and let Fusion 360 carry the heavy lifting so every print, driver practice, and match day feels lighter.

wro-cyrex-hardware.title: World Robot Olympiad RoboMission Senior Category. Build, Hardware
wro-cyrex-hardware.author: XLNC Cyrex — Hardware Squad
wro-cyrex-hardware.heroAlt: XLNC Cyrex manipulator prototype for WRO RoboMission
wro-cyrex-hardware.intro: In this series of articles and guides, as national and international medalists of WRO RoboMission Senior, we want to share our experience and tips for this category.

sections.title: Chapter 1. Game elements manipulators
paragraphs: Two pairs of claw manipulators sort and store various game elements.
Two long outer claws on the sides are designed:
1) to rotate and hold the Payload element;
2) to open the yellow field door and complete lever tasks;
3) to grab and move the Rocket noses element;
Two inner pink claws are intended for sorting and storing Bolt elements.

Inside the robot there are two internal pockets for storing the first two sorted bolts. They work on a trigger mechanism: when the outer claws touch, the compartments open and switch into bolt storage mode.

The rear of the robot includes a new upgrade according to the WRO Open Platform rules. An Arduino Nano board is linked to the EV3 brick via I2C, occupying one port. This Arduino controls a single servo motor for the rear claw. The rear claw was created in case of surprise challenges announced during competition days.

The robot used a large number of 3D-printed parts for optimal packaging. The principle: the fewer parts used, the simpler and more reliable every mechanism becomes. On the robot photos, the inner claws, trigger mechanism, storage pockets, and rear claw were fully made from PLA plastic following this principle.

images.alt: Overall view of XLNC Cyrex claws on RoboMission
images.caption: Fig. 1 — Overall view of XLNC Cyrex claws

images.alt: Outer claws for Payload and Rocket noses
images.caption: Fig. 2 — Outer claws for Payload and Rocket noses

images.alt: Inner pockets and trigger mechanism for Bolts
images.caption: Fig. 3 — Inner pockets and trigger mechanism for Bolts

sections.title: Chapter 2. EV3G blocks and innovative software solutions that were used during the world finals.
paragraphs: XLNC Cyrex used the following green blocks:
Drive:
The Drive block in LEGO EV3 programming is used for synchronous control of two motors (usually ports B and C), allowing the robot to move as a differential drive platform.
Our block logic is based on these parameters:
Steering - defines the ratio between left and right motor speeds.
A value of 0 means straight movement (both motors rotate at the same speed).
Positive or negative values create turns by slowing one motor and accelerating the other.
Power/Speed - sets motor speed.
Duration - defines how long the movement runs (time, rotations, or degrees).
Thus, the Drive block converts program logic into precise speed and direction control, ensuring straight motion and smooth turns.
Line following
Line following with two color sensors is based on feedback control. Sensors on the left and right under the robot constantly measure reflected light or surface color.
How it works:
Each sensor detects whether it is over the line (e.g., black) or the background (white).
The program adjusts motor speeds:
If the left sensor sees the line, the robot slows the left motor and speeds up the right motor to correct trajectory.
If the right sensor sees the line, the correction is reversed.
If both sensors see the background, the robot continues straight.
Using two sensors improves accuracy and stability compared to one sensor, reducing oscillations and letting the robot respond faster to line changes.
Turn Angle
Turning a robot to a specific angle in LEGO EV3 uses motor rotation measured by the built-in encoder.
How it works:
Each EV3 motor has an encoder that tracks shaft angle in degrees.
The program sets how many degrees one or both motors should rotate.
For on-the-spot turns:
One motor rotates forward, the other backward, or
Only one motor rotates while the other stays still.
The number of degrees directly corresponds to robot turn angle and depends on:
wheel diameter,
distance between wheels,
turn type (in place or arc).
Thus, Turn Angle provides precise, repeatable rotation using motor encoders.

images.alt: EV3G blocks: Drive, Line following, and Turn Angle
images.caption: Fig. 4 — Drive, Line following, and Turn Angle in EV3G

sections.title: Blue blocks we used
paragraphs: Claw Position
To control the claw position in LEGO EV3 Mindstorms, we use the blue motor block in position mode (angle control).
The principle is based on the motor encoder, which allows specific claw positions to be set and reproduced accurately.
In the program, each numeric value corresponds to a predefined claw position:
each value sets a specific motor rotation angle;
the rotation angle directly defines the claw state (open, half-open, closed, etc.).
When the program runs, the motor automatically turns to the specified angle and stops, even if the claw started elsewhere. This provides:
repeatable movements;
high positioning accuracy;
independence from motor runtime.
This approach lets us treat numeric values as logical mechanism states, simplifying control algorithms and improving reliability in manipulation tasks.

images.alt: Claw Position — blue block for manipulator positioning
images.caption: Fig. 5 — Claw Position blue block

sections.title: Servo-motor Position and robot tricks
paragraphs: Servo-motor Position
Robot tricks:
Pixy Camera on the EV3 robot

To recognize the color of game elements on the field, we used a Pixy Cam adapted for LEGO EV3. The camera processes images in real time and detects color signatures without heavy load on the main controller.

Connection between Pixy Cam and LEGO EV3 is via I²C (Inter-Integrated Circuit), providing stable and fast data transfer. I²C lets us receive structured data, including the color signature ID and the coordinates of the detected object.
System flow:
game elements are pre-trained in Pixy Cam as color signatures;
the camera analyzes the image and detects the target color;
Pixy Cam sends color type and object coordinates via I²C to EV3;
the robot program uses the data to decide actions (navigation, pickup, or sorting).

images.alt: Rear claw servo module and drive
images.caption: Fig. 6 — Servo module of the rear claw

images.alt: Pixy Camera on EV3 robot with angled mount
images.caption: Fig. 7 — Pixy Camera with adapter mount for EV3

wro-cyrex-hardware.closing: Using Pixy Cam with I²C improved color identification accuracy and speed compared to standard color sensors, and allowed stable performance under changing lighting and longer distances.

wro-robosport-ball-system.title: Build & Hardware by Naj, XLNC Fury
wro-robosport-ball-system.author: XLNC Fury — RoboSport Build Team
wro-robosport-ball-system.heroAlt: RoboSport flywheel launcher prototype with ball hopper
wro-robosport-ball-system.intro: In this series of articles and guides, as national and international medalists of WRO RoboSport, we want to share our experience and tips for this category.

sections.title: Part 1. Ball Management System
paragraphs: Building the ball “shot” mechanism in robotic tennis is critical and heavily impacts results. Since the main task is to throw balls, you must throw them quickly and to a precise distance, while also holding purple balls.

sections.title: Chapter 1. Shooting Mechanisms
paragraphs: There are several popular mechanisms for the first task.
Kicker
Fig. 1.1 example of a kicker robot
Fig. 1.2 example of a kicker robot
The construction is simple: the robot follows a path, collects orange balls, and “kicks” them upward and forward. Rubber bands or springs often add impulse for a sharp kick.
Pros: simple construction and fewer parts. Choose it if you cannot build more complex variants or lack resources/time. It is also easier and faster to program.
Cons:
cannot store balls, so trajectory is limited.
kick accuracy may be insufficient against strong opponents.
speed depends on engineering but is often low.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vEyGXVtalxY&pp=ygUNd3JvIHJvYm9zcG9ydA%3D%3D
An interesting match example with kicker robots.
Flywheel

Flywheel is one of the most popular RoboSport solutions. A rotating drum wrapped in elastic material “swallows” balls and “spits” them out. With tensioned rubber and rotation, balls launch at high speed.
Fig. 1.3 example of a flywheel robot
The back wall matters: as the drum rolls balls inside, a tensioned back wall can boost range and speed.
Fig. 1.4 Flywheel back wall
Fig 1.5 Rubber band layout on the flywheel back wall
Rubber bands are key to flywheel performance and should not be overdone. Options:
original LEGO 5x5 bands
office rubber bands.
Too much tension can cause shots that are too strong and long, sending balls outside the field. From experience, stretch rubber until it lightens. Distance is less important than accuracy.
Fig 1.6 Original LEGO rubber bands
This mechanism is, in our view, the best option. World champions use it. It also makes it easiest to integrate other robot functions. However, it is comparatively harder to program.
The flywheel drum is driven by one large motor and gearing.

images.alt: Fig. 1.1 example of a kicker robot
images.caption: Fig. 1.1 — example of a kicker robot

images.alt: Fig. 1.2 example of a kicker robot
images.caption: Fig. 1.2 — example of a kicker robot

images.alt: Fig. 1.3 example of a flywheel robot
images.caption: Fig. 1.3 — example of a flywheel robot

images.alt: Fig. 1.4 Flywheel back wall
images.caption: Fig. 1.4 — Flywheel back wall

images.alt: Fig. 1.5 Rubber band layout on the flywheel back wall
images.caption: Fig. 1.5 — Rubber band layout on the flywheel back wall

images.alt: Fig. 1.6 Original LEGO rubber bands
images.caption: Fig. 1.6 — Original LEGO rubber bands

sections.title: Chapter 2. Ball Holding & Tracking
paragraphs: Ball holding
The second mission in robotic tennis is holding the purple ball on your half of the field. We covered detection in the programming section; here we discuss hardware.

We held the purple ball in a special compartment behind the flywheel wall. The wall is driven by a medium motor and raises to change the ball path. Instead of going up to the launch zone, the purple ball rolls under the wall into a compartment between motors, where it stays until the end of the game.
https://youtu.be/EeTfra6aHig
Video example of the holding mechanism (note: the robot in the video holds an orange ball for demo purposes; in the real game you must hold the purple ball).
Fig. 2.1 Example of holding an orange ball inside the robot
Tracking

Besides initializing color through cameras, the robot has color sensors to detect balls inside. They face downward inside the robot above the flywheel exit. We recommend LEGO color sensors because their polling rate is high, and exact color accuracy is less important than data presence (explained in the software section).
Fig 2.2 LEGO Color Sensor

sections.title: Chapter 3. AI Cameras
paragraphs: Since the LEGO EV3 brick has limited compute and cannot run computer vision, cameras with onboard AI are used to handle processing and simplify communication.
Pixy Camera
https://pixycam.com/pixy-lego/
The most popular and well-developed camera option. Lessons and guides are included in the programming part of this article and in WRO Future Engineers articles.
Fig 3.1 Pixy2 for Lego Mindstorms EV3 camera
The camera has two M2 mounting holes, which is inconvenient for LEGO beams. Below we attach a 3D-printed adapter file with an angled mount.
[file will be posted on the site]
Recommended infill for printing: 15-30%, plastic type is not important.
You can buy PixyCam on OLX or in the KZRobotics chat, as well as on eBay and AliExpress.

sections.title: Part 4. Useful materials
paragraphs: Useful materials for this category:
Lecture from the WRO 2025 training camp for RoboSport
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FoRNLSMaYOM&t=8s

wro-robosport-ball-system.closing: You can buy PixyCam on OLX or in the KZRobotics chat, as well as on eBay and AliExpress.
